title: Analysis of Curve with Implicit Diff-Polar

content.description:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The graph of the curve <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, given by <math alttext="4 times x squared, plus 3 times y squared, plus 6 y, equals 9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is shown in the figure above.
content.question: (a) Show that <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals the fraction with numerator negative 4 x, and denominator 3 times, open parenthesis, y plus 1, close parenthesis, end fraction" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>y</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

frqParts.text: (a) Show that <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals the fraction with numerator negative 4 x, and denominator 3 times, open parenthesis, y plus 1, close parenthesis, end fraction" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>y</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

(b) Using the information from part (a), find <math alttext="the second derivative of y with respect to x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) In polar coordinates, the curve <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="r equals, the fraction with numerator 3, and denominator 2 plus sine theta, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to 2 pi" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="the derivative of r with respect to theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. As <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increases, on what intervals is the distance between the origin and the point <math alttext="with coordinates r comma theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing? Give a reason for your answer.

(d) Let <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region inside curve <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as defined in part (c), but outside the curve <math alttext="r equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write, but do not evaluate, an integral expression for the area of <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

unit.text: 3: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
